items.title: L’inganno felino: scopri quale animale si mimetizza tra questi gatti
items.description:
Nel panorama delle sfide visive online, sta riscuotendo notevole successo un test che mette alla prova l’acutezza dell’osservazione.
L'articolo L’inga
items.body:
Sostenibilità
                             
                                                
                                        L’inganno felino: scopri quale animale si mimetizza tra questi gatti

Roberto Arciola

Novembre 7, 2025

La sfida del mimetismo: il gufo tra i gatti (www.greenstyle.it)

Nel panorama delle sfide visive online, sta riscuotendo notevole successo un test che mette alla prova l’acutezza dell’osservazione.

Solo l’1% dei partecipanti riesce a individuare l’animale mimetizzato, confermando quanto la percezione visiva richieda attenzione e pazienza. Questa prova non è solo un divertente passatempo, ma un vero esercizio cognitivo che invita a sviluppare la concentrazione e la capacità di cogliere dettagli nascosti.
L’immagine protagonista del test presenta una moltitudine di gatti, ognuno con pelliccia e sguardo differenti, ma la vera sfida consiste nel scoprire un gufo comune (Asio otus) abilmente mimetizzato. Il gufo, noto per il suo piumaggio che si confonde perfettamente con l’ambiente circostante, rappresenta un esempio straordinario di mimetismo criptico, una strategia naturale che consente a molte specie animali di nascondersi dai predatori o di sorprendere le prede.
Questo tipo di mimetismo è molto diffuso nel regno animale: dal camaleonte che cambia colore al richiamo visivo della farfalla Foglia asiatica, fino al bradipo il cui pelo ospita minuscole alghe che lo occultano tra i rami. Nel caso del gufo comune, il piumaggio maculato e i ciuffi auricolari contribuiscono a spezzare la sua sagoma, rendendolo quasi invisibile all’occhio distratto.
La sfida visiva, dunque, diventa uno stimolo a rallentare l’osservazione e ad affinare la capacità di notare ciò che si cela dietro l’apparente omogeneità dell’immagine. Durante la ricerca, è possibile scorgere anche espressioni buffe e dettagli insoliti nei gatti, che arricchiscono l’esperienza e offrono uno spunto di riflessione sul potenziale cognitivo umano.
Il gufo comune: caratteristiche e curiosità
Asio otus, il gufo comune, è un rapace notturno presente in Europa, Asia e Nord America, che predilige boschi e foreste di conifere. Misura tra i 35 e i 40 centimetri di lunghezza, con un’apertura alare che può raggiungere i 100 centimetri. Caratteristica peculiare sono i due ciuffi di piume sulle orecchie, che non influenzano l’udito ma contribuiscono al suo aspetto mimetico.
Nonostante non possa muovere gli occhi, il gufo comune è in grado di ruotare la testa fino a 270°, una capacità che gli consente di mantenere una visuale ampia e precisa durante la caccia notturna. La sua dieta è variegata e comprende piccoli mammiferi come topi, talpe e scoiattoli, oltre ad insetti e uccelli.
Durante il giorno, il gufo si rifugia in cavità di alberi o ruderi, mimetizzandosi perfettamente grazie al piumaggio. Durante l’inverno, è l’unico rapace notturno che forma dormitori collettivi, spesso anche in zone urbane, un comportamento che probabilmente favorisce la protezione reciproca e lo scambio di informazioni sulle fonti di cibo.
La diffusione del gufo comune è piuttosto ampia e la specie è classificata a rischio minimo di estinzione, ma la crescente urbanizzazione e il degrado degli habitat naturali rappresentano sfide costanti per la sua conservazione.
Il valore cognitivo dei test visivi e il mimetismo in natura(www.greenstyle.it)
La difficoltà nel trovare il gufo nascosto tra i gatti non dipende solo dalla sua abilità mimetica, ma anche dalla complessità della percezione visiva umana. La maggior parte delle persone tende a focalizzarsi sugli elementi più evidenti, mentre il cervello deve allenarsi a cogliere sottili differenze cromatiche e forme nascoste.
Questi test visivi, oltre a intrattenere, hanno effetti positivi sulla capacità di concentrazione e di attenzione ai dettagli. Essi invitano a superare la frustrazione iniziale e a perseverare, sviluppando così pazienza e determinazione. La soddisfazione nel riconoscere finalmente il gufo nascosto evidenzia l’importanza della pratica e dell’osservazione consapevole.
In natura, il mimetismo rappresenta una strategia evolutiva essenziale per la sopravvivenza. Oltre al mimetismo criptico, esistono altre forme come il mimetismo fanerico, che consiste nell’imitare specie pericolose per scoraggiare i predatori, e il mimetismo mülleriano, dove specie innocue si somigliano a vicenda per confondere eventuali minacce.
Il gufo comune è un perfetto esempio di mimetismo criptico difensivo, che lo protegge durante il riposo diurno. Le sue abitudini e il suo aspetto hanno anche ispirato molte rappresentazioni culturali, dal ruolo di animale saggio nelle fiabe alla presenza simbolica nelle saghe moderne come quella di Harry Potter, dove i gufi sono messaggeri e compagni dei maghi.

items.title: Nuovo decreto nazionale contro il greenwashing: cosa cambia per le Aziende italiane?
items.description: Il Consiglio dei Ministri ha approvato il decreto legislativo che recepisce la Direttiva (UE) 2024/825, dedicata alla “responsabilizzazione dei consum
items.body:
Nuovo decreto nazionale contro il greenwashing: cosa cambia per le Aziende italiane?

07.11.2025 -                                 Aziende

condividi:

Il Consiglio dei Ministri ha approvato il decreto legislativo che recepisce la Direttiva (UE) 2024/825, dedicata alla “responsabilizzazione dei consumatori per la transizione verde”.

Si tratta di una approvazione “in esame preliminare”, utile a rendere pubblica la proposta e a consentire i passaggi consultivi obbligatori prima dell’adozione finale.

Il decreto si inserisce nella strategia europea per rafforzare la fiducia dei consumatori rispetto ai prodotti realmente più sostenibili, imponendo regole chiare sull’uso dei cosiddetti green claims, ovvero le dichiarazioni ambientali che le Aziende utilizzano per promuovere i propri prodotti a maggiore livello di eco-compatibilità.

Le nuove disposizioni riguardano tutte le imprese che comunicano vantaggi ambientali o sociali dei propri prodotti e proprie attività, sia nella pubblicità che nelle etichette o nella presentazione dei prodotti.

L’obiettivo è assicurare che ogni affermazione di carattere ambientale sia fondata su dati verificabili e non ingannevoli.

Un nuovo quadro contro il greenwashing delle Aziende scorrette

Il decreto stabilisce che le dichiarazioni ambientali dovranno essere chiare, pertinenti e supportate da prove scientifiche, preferibilmente basate su metodologie riconosciute a livello europeo.

Vengono vietate le asserzioni generiche come “eco-friendly”, “sostenibile” o “a impatto zero” se non accompagnate da informazioni specifiche che ne dimostrino la veridicità.

Sarà inoltre vietato comunicare la sostenibilità di un prodotto basandosi esclusivamente su un singolo aspetto o parte del ciclo di vita, ignorando impatti ambientali significativi di altre sue fasi produttive.

Il provvedimento, dunque, punta a contrastare i messaggi ambientali ingannevoli e a rafforzare la fiducia dei consumatori, oltre che a limitare il rischio di greenwashing.

Opportunità per il Made in Italy sostenibile: i green claims delle Aziende

Il decreto deve essere visto anche come una tutela per le aziende virtuose: valorizza chi investe realmente in sostenibilità, proteggendolo da concorrenza sleale e messaggi ingannevoli.

Come sottolineato dal Ministero delle Imprese e del Made in Italy (MIMIT), la trasparenza diventa così una leva strategica competitiva, in linea con la crescente sensibilità ambientale dei mercati europei.

Negli ultimi anni, infatti, la reputazione ambientale e sociale dei prodotti italiani è diventata un fattore chiave di differenziazione sui mercati internazionali.

Per molti settori, dall’agroalimentare al tessile, dal design alla cosmetica, all'agri-food la trasparenza diventa un marchio di qualità, capace di consolidare la fiducia dei consumatori e attrarre investitori sempre più attenti ai criteri ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance).

In questo senso, il decreto può essere letto come un passaggio culturale, oltre che normativo: incoraggia le imprese a integrare la sostenibilità in modo strutturale, trasformando le dichiarazioni ambientali da semplici strumenti di marketing a elementi misurabili e verificabili della performance aziendale.

Le conseguenze per le aziende italiane

Le funzioni di marketing e comunicazione delle Aziende dovranno coordinarsi più strettamente con i reparti tecnici e con i consulenti ambientali, e dovranno integrare procedure di verifica interna e strumenti di analisi come la Life Cycle Assessment (LCA)

L'uso della tecnica dell'LCA permette di garantire che ogni messaggio pubblicitario sia supportato da dati di produzione verificabili e correttamente analizzati: avevamo già parlato dell’importanza dei green claims e dell’utilizzo di tecniche LCA in un nostro precedente articolo.

Chi non sarà in grado di dimostrare la veridicità delle proprie dichiarazioni, oltre ai danni reputazionali, rischia sanzioni amministrative proporzionate alla gravità e alla diffusione del messaggio ingannevole.

Anche prima dell’entrata in vigore di questo decreto, le autorità italiane hanno iniziato a intervenire contro comunicazioni ambientali ritenute fuorvianti.

Un caso significativo è quello di San Benedetto e il claim “CO₂ Impatto Zero”: in quel caso, l’Autorità Garante della Concorrenza e del Mercato (AGCM) ha contestato il claim utilizzato dalla linea “Ecogreen” del marchio San Benedetto, ritenendolo troppo ambizioso e privo di adeguate evidenze scientifiche.

L’azienda ha accettato di rimuovere lo slogan e le grafiche fortemente evocative, ha introdotto un QR code nelle etichette che rimanda a una sezione di sostenibilità con dati documentati, e ha ridefinito il proprio messaggio ambientale in “Il Nostro Impegno Concreto”.

Questo esempio dimostra concretamente che, anche senza un decreto ancora pienamente operativo, comunicazioni ambientali generiche possono già essere oggetto di intervento da parte delle autorità competenti con l’obiettivo di scoraggiare pratiche scorrette e tutelare i consumatori.

items.title: Copernicus, il 2025 sarà quasi sicuramente tra i tre anni più caldi di sempre
items.description:
Secondo le rilevazioni, il 2025 sarà forse a pari merito con il 2023, attualmente il secondo anno più caldo
The post Copernicus, il 2025 sarà quasi si
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Il 2025 finirà quasi certamente come il secondo o terzo anno più caldo mai registrato. A riportarlo sono i dati del Servizio Cambiamento Climatico di Copernicus. Secondo le rilevazioni, il 2025 sarà forse a pari merito con il 2023, attualmente il secondo anno più caldo, e dietro al 2024, l’anno più caldo mai registrato. Sebbene il 2025 potrebbe non raggiungere 1,5 °C al di sopra del livello preindustriale, la temperatura media globale per il periodo 2023-2025 supererà probabilmente 1,5 °C. Questo risultato rappresenterebbe la prima media triennale a registrare questo risultato nel periodo strumentale. La preoccupazione è fortissima perché ormai il balzo di temperatura iniziato nel 2023 si sta confermando come tendenza. Gran parte dei politici paiono non rendersi conto delle implicazioni per la vita di tanti cittadini e per la stessa solidità e tenuta delle società e delle economie. Dobbiamo fare di tutto per arrestare questa tendenza, e la ricetta è drammaticamente semplice: smettere di bruciare i combustibili fossili e fermare la deforestazione. È responsabilità di ciascun Paese e speriamo diventi anche responsabilità comune alla COP30 di Belém, con un vero e proprio percorso di uscita dalle cause delle emissioni climalteranti, dunque dai combustibili fossili. Ci vuole tanto coraggio, tanta determinazione, ma soprattutto tanta collaborazione da parte di tuttiMariagrazia Midulla, responsabile Clima ed Energia del WWF Italia I dati di ottobre 2025 Le previsioni di Copernicus si basano anche sugli ultimi dati di Ottobre 2025. Il mese appena concluso è stato il terzo ottobre più caldo a livello globale. La temperatura media dell’aria superficiale è stata di 0,70 °C al di sopra della media di ottobre 1991-2020. Ottobre 2025 è stato di 1,55 °C superiore alla media stimata per il periodo 1850-1900 utilizzata per definire il livello preindustriale. Si tratta del primo mese sopra 1,50 °C dall’aprile 2025. items.title: Xylella, un report denuncia come il corporativismo ha distrutto gli ulivi pugliesi
items.description:
Il WWF presenta “La fastidiosa Xylella”, un’analisi approfondita che fa il punto a oltre 12 anni dall’inizio dell’emergenza in Puglia
The post Xylella
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie In occasione della Giornata Nazionale dell’Agricoltura, il WWF presenta il rapporto “La fastidiosa Xylella”, un’analisi approfondita che fa il punto a oltre dodici anni dall’inizio dell’emergenza in Puglia. Il documento valuta le scelte compiute dall’Unione europea, dal Ministero dell’Agricoltura, dalla Regione Puglia e dalle principali associazioni agricole nel tentativo di contenere il batterio. Un’agricoltura dai due volti Dal rapporto emerge il ritratto di un’agricoltura “Made in Italy” dai due volti: da un lato, gli agricoltori custodi del paesaggio e degli agroecosistemi, protagonisti di buone pratiche e resilienza; dall’altro, un sistema corporativo segnato da alleanze strumentali tra alcune associazioni di categoria, imprenditori agricoli, decisori politici e una parte del mondo accademico e della ricerca. Secondo il WWF, tali dinamiche, unite a provvedimenti normativi e interventi sproporzionati, spesso privi di solide basi scientifiche, hanno contribuito a devastare il territorio degli ulivi monumentali — un patrimonio di inestimabile valore ambientale e paesaggistico — proprio mentre si dichiarava di volerlo proteggere. Eradicazione forzata Il caso Xylella rappresenta oggi un esempio emblematico dei limiti della ricerca agronomica nel nostro Paese e dei pregiudizi ancora diffusi nei confronti dei principi e delle buone pratiche dell’agroecologia. Il batterio della Xylella, arrivato in Puglia probabilmente attraverso piante di caffè importate dall’America centrale, è stato contrastato principalmente con l’abbattimento massivo degli ulivi infetti, inclusi esemplari secolari e millenari. Le norme hanno imposto l’estirpazione non solo delle piante colpite, ma anche di tutti gli ulivi entro un raggio di 100 metri – ridotto a 50 dal 2022 – privilegiando così la logica dell’eradicazione forzata. Tale approccio è stato adottato nonostante dal 2015 il batterio fosse già considerato endemico e non eradicabile, trascurando strategie ecologiche mirate alla salute dell’agroecosistema e alla resilienza delle piante alla malattia. Ogni tentativo di trattare gli ulivi con metodi agroecologici è stato giudicato inefficace, e questo messaggio, partito dagli ambienti scientifici, si è rapidamente diffuso tra politici, associazioni di categoria, tecnici e agricoltori. Risultati disastrosi Il risultato è stato la distruzione e l’abbandono di centinaia di ettari di oliveti, senza reali tentativi di contenimento basati su pratiche ecologiche. Solo alcuni agricoltori coraggiosi e disobbedienti hanno scelto di sperimentare approcci agroecologici, spesso osteggiati o derisi. Grazie alla loro tenacia, oggi si osserva la ripresa vegetativa di ulivi un tempo considerati irrimediabilmente infetti, tornati a produrre un olio di alta qualità: una prova concreta dell’esistenza di alternative agroecologiche per contenere la Xylella attraverso la cura e il ripristino degli agroecosistemi. La strategia degli abbattimenti ha inoltre generato flussi finanziari stimati in oltre 600 milioni di euro, alimentando speculazioni e conflitti di interesse legati alla sostituzione degli ulivi monumentali con impianti intensivi e superintensivi di varietà di ulivi (cultivar) brevettate ritenute più resistenti alla Xylella. Questo processo ha portato anche alla demolizione della normativa di tutela del paesaggio storico degli ulivi millenari e alla perdita di un patrimonio culturale e naturale unico, frutto dell’incapacità di immaginare un modello agricolo diverso, in cui l’agricoltore sia davvero custode dell’ambiente. I danni dell’agricoltura intensiva I dati dell’ultimo rapporto dell’Agenzia europea per l’Ambiente (ottobre 2024) confermano la gravità della situazione: l’agricoltura intensiva rimane la principale causa di perdita di biodiversità in Europa e in Italia, con l’80% degli habitat protetti in cattivo stato di conservazione, il 60-70% dei suoli degradati e un uso delle risorse naturali pari a 1,5 volte la capacità del pianeta di rigenerarle. Questi numeri impongono una riflessione urgente sulle pratiche agricole dominanti e sulle scelte delle filiere agroalimentari. La lezione della Xylella è chiara: quando si applicano i principi dell’agroecologia e le politiche adeguate e la ricerca scientifica indipendente li sostengono, è possibile integrare il ripristino ambientale nelle pratiche agricole. Tutto questo garantendo sicurezza alimentare, tutela della biodiversità e salvaguardia del paesaggio. È tempo di abbandonare il modello di produzione agricola intensivo, centrato sulla massimizzazione delle rese a breve termine, degradando il territorio e la sua biodiversità, per accelerare la transizione agroecologica dei nostri sistemi agroalimentari. Serve un cambio di paradigma che metta al centro gli agricoltori come veri custodi dell’ambiente, valorizzando le pratiche che rigenerano il suolo, preservano l’acqua, proteggono gli habitat naturali e mantengono viva la ricchezza genetica e culturale dei paesaggi italiani. La Giornata Nazionale dell’Agricoltura La Giornata Nazionale dell’Agricoltura, istituita dalla Legge n. 24 del 28 febbraio 2024, si celebra in Italia la seconda domenica di novembre. Quest’anno cadrà il 9 novembre e rappresenta un’occasione per riconoscere il ruolo fondamentale degli agricoltori come custodi dell’ambiente, del territorio e della biodiversità. Tuttavia, questo riconoscimento non distingue tra i diversi modelli produttivi, mettendo sullo stesso piano gli agricoltori virtuosi, che praticano agroecologia, e coloro che seguono modelli intensivi basati sull’uso di sostanze chimiche di sintesi, responsabili della perdita di biodiversità e della semplificazione degli agroecosistemi. La fastidiosa Xylella, i due volti dell'agricoltura In occasione della seconda edizione della Giornata Nazionale dell’Agricoltura, il WWF presenta un rapporto sull'emergenza Xylella in Puglia

items.title: Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation slowdown suppresses Atlantic Niño variability
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 06 November 2025

Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation slowdown suppresses Atlantic Niño variability
                    Pedro Freire-Souza1, Gabriel M. Pontes2,3,4, Laurie Menviel2,3 & …Ilana Wainer1 Show authors

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 355 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric scienceClimate and Earth system modellingClimate changeClimate-change impactsOcean sciencesPhysical oceanography

AbstractfThe Atlantic Niño is the dominant mode of interannual variability in the Tropical Atlantic with significant impacts on local and remote climate patterns. Despite recent advances in understanding the mechanisms leading to weakened Atlantic Niño variability, its primary causes remain unknown. Here, we use an Earth System Model to show that the strength of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) modulates air-sea feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic through both atmospheric and oceanic teleconnections. The combination of a southward shift of the Intertropical Convergence Zone and the propagation of oceanic downwelling Kelvin waves due to an AMOC weakening, generated in the subpolar North Atlantic, deepens the eastern thermocline and weakens the equatorial trade winds, leading to a decoupling in air-sea feedbacks. Finally, we show that adding the effect of meltwater in future projections reduces the upwelling feedback strength by 60 ± 6% in 2100, with potential changes in the Atlantic Niño-driven rainfall.

IntroductionThe Atlantic Niño is the primary mode of variability in the tropical Atlantic Ocean1,2,3, significantly affecting not only tropical rainfall, including the Sahel and Amazon basins precipitation4,5, but also remote extratropical regions6 and tropical inter-basin processes7,8,9,10. Atlantic Niño events result from anomalous exchange of heat and momentum between the ocean and the overlying atmosphere. Positive sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies in the central and eastern equatorial Atlantic alter the sea level pressure and weaken the easterly trade winds. Anomalous winds perturb the thermocline below, generating downwelling oceanic Kelvin waves that travel eastward along the Equator and deepen the eastern equatorial thermocline. A deepened thermocline increases the heat content within the mixed layer, further enhancing the initial positive SST anomalies1,2,3.Recent studies have identified a significant persistent decrease in the Atlantic Niño variability since the 1970’s11,12,13, and this variability is projected to further weaken under global warming14. The Atlantic Niño decline has been mostly attributed to a decoupling between surface and subsurface temperature variations due to a persistent deeper thermocline11,12,14, but also with contributions from weakened ocean-atmosphere coupling15 and basin-wide warming related to climate change12,13. Weakened air-sea coupling in the equatorial Atlantic is caused by weaker and more stable winds that reduce the effectiveness of wind anomalies in promoting changes in the thermocline15. Rising SSTs due to enhanced CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere increase the heat flux from the ocean to the atmosphere, thus damping the initial positive SST anomalies13.Although changes in Atlantic Niño feedbacks can be directly affected by global warming, these could also be driven or amplified by teleconnection processes16,17. The equatorial Atlantic can be influenced by the variability of the Pacific and Indian Oceans on inter-annual to decadal timescales through tropical inter-basin interactions. First, El Niño events, characterized by positive SST anomalies in the central-eastern Pacific, displace the Atlantic Walker cell eastwards, resulting in weaker trade winds over the Atlantic basin18. As such, persistent enhanced El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) activity can possibly lead to weaker Atlantic Niño variability. Secondly, warm anomalies in the tropical Indian Ocean intensify the Atlantic equatorial winds through a tropical baroclinic response19, thus possibly favouring enhanced Atlantic Niño variability. However, the recent period of reduced ENSO activity20,21 and the CO2-driven Indian Ocean warming are inconsistent with a decreased Atlantic Niño variability through tropical basin interaction mechanisms. Lastly, the intensity of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), which is the major circulation system in the Atlantic Ocean, has been shown to affect SST variability in the Indian22 and Pacific23 Oceans. In the Atlantic Ocean, a weakening of the AMOC leads to significant warming in the Tropical South Atlantic due to a deepening of the thermocline24,25. The AMOC weakening also decreases the southeastern trade winds over the Atlantic basin17, which could impact the Atlantic Niño variability. Despite being an ongoing topic of research, there is increasing proxy-data and observational evidence suggesting that the AMOC has weakened since the mid-20th century25,26,27, possibly consistent with reduced Atlantic Niño activity since the 1970’s. However, the response of equatorial SST variability to AMOC changes is yet to be elucidated. In this context, we first perform idealized subpolar North Atlantic freshwater hosing experiments with an Earth System Model to investigate AMOC-driven teleconnection processes that could reduce the Atlantic Niño variability. We then use our results to evaluate the sensitivity of the Atlantic Niño variability to an AMOC weakening under global warming.ResultsAtlantic Niño response to an AMOC weakeningTo investigate the impact of an AMOC weakening on Atlantic Niño variability and dynamics, we perform numerical simulations with the Australian Community Climate and Earth System Simulator version 1.5 (ACCESS-ESM1.5)25,28. The ACCESS-ESM1.5 model is skilful in simulating both AMOC intensity and Equatorial Atlantic mean state and feedbacks, which allows a realistic assessment of the linkage between the two phenomena. Firstly, the model simulates the AMOC at a strength of 19 Sv (Fig. 1a) in the pre-industrial scenario, in agreement with direct AMOC estimates of the mid-twentieth century (20.1 Sv from ref. 29). Furthermore, the model captures the observed equatorial Atlantic mean state during the peak season of the Atlantic Niño (June-July-August (JJA)), including the negative zonal SST gradient and thermocline slope (Fig. 2d)15. Lastly, the ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulates the relationship between coupled processes in the equatorial Atlantic in the pre-industrial climate (Fig. 2a–c), important for Atlantic Niño development and known as Bjerkenes Feedbacks, with correlation coefficients greater than 0.7 (Supplementary Table S1), and simulating feedback strengths in close agreement with observations (Fig. 2a–c)14,30.Fig. 1: Structural and variability changes in Atlantic Niño due to an AMOC collapse.a Temporal evolution of the AMOC strength, defined as the annual-mean maximum Atlantic Ocean meridional streamfunction (Sv) at 26∘N in the AMOC-on and AMOC-off experiments. b Atlantic Niño index, defined as sea surface temperature anomalies (SSTa) in the eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3 region; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) in June-July-August. Shading indicates the long-term (second-degree polynomial) variability trend (21-years running standard deviation) of the Atlantic Niño index. c, d Atlantic Niño index regressed onto SSTa in AMOC-on and AMOC-off, respectively e, f Atlantic Niño impact over precipitation, wind, and sea-level pressure fields in AMOC-on (d) and AMOC-off experiments (e). Shading indicates the Atlantic Ninõ index regressed against precipitation anomalies (\({{mm.day}^{-1}} ^{\circ }{\text{C}}^{-1}\)), contour lines represent the index regressed against sea level pressure anomalies (hPa ∘C−1), and vectors represent the index projected onto wind anomalies \((m.{\text{s}{}^{-1}}^{\circ }{\text{C}}^{-1})\). Stippling in panels c–f represent regions in which the linear regression coefficients are statistically significant at the 95% level based on 1000-sample bootstrapping. c, e and d, f were computed using the AMOC-on (−100 to 0 years) and AMOC-off (400 to 500 years) time slices, respectively. A mask over the continents was applied to the pressure data to facilitate visualization.Full size imageFig. 2: Temporal evolution of the Bjerknes feedbacks and Equatorial Atlantic Climatology.Components of the Bjerknes Feedbacks estimated through linear regression of a eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) SST anomalies onto western equatorial Atlantic (ATL4; 3∘S-3∘N, 40∘W-20∘W) zonal wind stress anomalies during JJA, b equatorial thermocline slope anomalies during JJA onto ATL4 zonal wind stress anomalies during March-April-May and c SST anomalies in ATL3 during JJA onto thermocline depth anomalies in ATL3. The equatorial thermocline slope is computed as the difference in the mean depth of thermocline, defined as the 20 °C isotherm, between ATL3 and ATL4. Colours indicate four different periods: AMOC-on (blue), between 50 and 150 years after the addition of freshwater (green), between 150 and 250 years after the addition of freshwater (yellow), and during the AMOC-off period (red). α indicates the regression coefficient. d Trends in upper-ocean temperature averaged between 3∘S and 3∘N in the first 100 years of the hosing experiment. Horizontal lines indicate the depth of tthe hermocline for the AMOC-on (blue) and AMOC-off (red) periods. Temporal evolution of annual mean e equatorial thermocline slope, f thermocline depth in ATL3, g sea level pressure in the North Atlantic Subtropical High region (35∘N-40∘N, 60∘W-20∘W) and h zonal wind stress in ATL4.Full size imageWe first perform an idealized AMOC shutdown experiment by adding 0.4 Sv of freshwater in the subpolar North Atlantic under constant pre-industrial background climate conditions (Methods). This idealized forcing was implemented to provide a robust assessment of the impact of AMOC strength on the global climate. Given the high internal variability of the equatorial Atlantic, this forcing provides a high signal-to-noise ratio. In this water hosing simulation, the AMOC takes approximately 170 years to decline from an intensity of 19 Sv to below 5 Sv (Fig. 1a). This period of rapid weakening is followed by a slower reduction, ultimately ending up in a new equilibrium state, when the AMOC strength stabilizes at around 3 Sv (hereafter referred to as AMOC-off; red line in Fig. 1a). This simulation is compared to the pre-industrial control run31 (hereafter referred as AMOC-on).The collapse of the AMOC significantly reduces the northward Atlantic Ocean heat transport, leading to accumulation of heat in the Southern Hemisphere and a deficit in the Northern Hemisphere, thereby reversing the inter-hemispheric temperature contrast (Supplementary Fig. 1). In response to this, the atmospheric circulation in the Northern Hemisphere intensifies in an attempt to export the excess energy out of the Southern Hemisphere. In the equatorial Atlantic, these global changes drive a southward shift of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) and a weakening the equatorial southeasterly trade winds (Supplementary Fig. 1).The freshwater hosing induces a gradual weakening (Fig. 1b and Supplementary Fig. 2) of the Atlantic Niño, with a 21% weakening between years 50 and 100, and ultimately reaching a 37% weakening between years 400 and 500 (Supplementary Fig. 2) compared to the unperturbed state (AMOC-on). This weakening is accompanied by a significant change in the spatial pattern of the Atlantic Niño SST anomalies (Fig. 1c, d). Under a collapsed AMOC, the warming core shrinks towards the central equatorial Atlantic, with cooling observed in the southeastern Atlantic (Fig. 1d). The new spatial pattern results in substantially different wind and precipitation responses (Fig. 1e, f). The classic positive Atlantic Niño fingerprint causes negative sea-level pressure anomalies in the eastern equatorial Atlantic, weakening the southeasterly winds and shifting the ITCZ southward. This results in increased precipitation along the equator, including the Amazon and Congo basins (Fig. 1e). On the other hand, the anomalous surface pattern under a collapsed AMOC drives higher sea level pressure in the southeastern South Atlantic (Fig. 1f), strengthening the southeasterlies. This leads to drier conditions in south equatorial and tropical western Africa, while increasing precipitation in northeastern Brazil. The new pattern shows a diminished impact of the Atlantic Niño on eastern Amazon rainfall. It is important noting that the tropical Atlantic is one of the remote regions most strongly impacted by an AMOC collapse. As such, large changes in the mean state under this scenario (Supplementary Fig. 1) can possibly alter the ocean-atmosphere feedbacks at play in the equatorial Atlantic mode, as we discuss in the following section.Weakened ocean-atmosphere coupling due to an AMOC collapseTo investigate the mechanisms behind changes in the variability of the Atlantic Niño when the AMOC weakens and collapses, we evaluate the three main ocean-atmosphere coupling feedbacks (Bjerknes Feedbacks), related to the development of Atlantic Niño events30. First, the zonal advection feedback (BF1) measures the amplification of the response of eastern equatorial SST anomalies to anomalous zonal wind stress in the western equatorial Atlantic. Secondly, the thermocline feedback (BF2) identifies the intensity of the response of the thermocline slope due to changes in zonal wind stress. Finally, the upwelling feedback (BF3) measures the effect of local changes in the eastern Atlantic thermocline depth on SST anomalies (Methods).To understand how the Bjerknes feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic are changing due to the weakening of the AMOC, we split the North Atlantic hosing experiment into 4 periods: before the addition of freshwater (P0; AMOC-on; blue in Fig. 2); between 50 and 150 years after the addition of freshwater (P1; green); between 150 and 250 years after the addition of freshwater (P2; yellow); and during the AMOC-off period (P3; red). Results indicate that its weakening during the transient AMOC slow-down (P1 and P2) is mostly driven by a weakened upwelling feedback (BF3), and with significant contribution from the zonal advective feedback (BF1). During P1 and P2, BF3 weakens by approximately 60% and 120%, respectively (Fig. 2c), while the zonal advective feedback (BF1) weakens by 40% and 92%, respectively (Fig. 2a). On the other hand, the thermocline feedback (BF2; Fig. 2b) increases by up to 20% during P1 and P2. Finally, under a collapsed AMOC (P3), the reduced Atlantic Niño variability is primarily caused by the reduction in the upwelling feedback (BF3), followed by the zonal advective feedback (BF1). The thermocline feedback (BF2) reduces by only 30%, indicating that the reduced variability is primarily driven by BF1 and BF3.In understanding how an AMOC weakening can affect the Bjerknes feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic, we initially evaluate the temporal evolution of the main features of the coupled tropical climate. First, trends in mixed-layer temperatures (Fig. 2d) indicate a more pronounced warming in the subsurface layer of the eastern equatorial Atlantic, resulting in a deeper thermocline (Fig. 2f) and consequently a weaker influence on surface waters (e.g., weakened BF3). Furthermore, the western equatorial Atlantic experiences a subsurface cooling trend, resulting in a shallower thermocline. Together, these changes reverse the thermocline slope as the AMOC collapses (Fig. 2e).Here, we identify two teleconnection processes from the subarctic North Atlantic that contribute to reversing the equatorial thermocline slope. First, an atmospheric teleconnection is triggered by reduced northward oceanic heat transport (OHT). To compensate for the heat deficit in the Northern Hemisphere, the atmospheric circulation intensifies and expands southwards to export heat from the Southern Hemisphere32,33 (Supplementary Fig. 1). This process is also identified in our simulations by strengthened atmospheric subtropical circulation in the North Atlantic (Fig. 2g) and a southward shift of the ITCZ (Supplementary Fig. 3a). This meridional atmospheric teleconnection drives the weakening of the equatorial winds (Fig. 2h and Supplementary Fig. 3b,c), which ultimately act on decreasing the thermocline slope.Secondly, an oceanic teleconnection is triggered by displaced isopycnals in the subarctic region, due to freshwater input and reduced deep ocean convection. Downwelling Kelvin waves propagate along the western boundary and reach the equatorial Atlantic25,34,35,36. In the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model, we assess the propagation of coastal Kelvin waves through their impact on the baroclinicity of the mean flow in the western boundary currents of the North Atlantic - namely, the Gulf Stream and the North Brazil Current (see Methods, Supplementary Fig. 4). As baroclinic Kelvin waves propagate due to an increased density gradient towards the boundary, the offshore large-scale wind-driven pressure gradient weakens. Thus weakening the boundary currents through the thermal-wind balance34,37,38,39,40. An analysis of the western boundary currents reveals that Kelvin wave propagation reduces the zonal density gradients in both the Gulf Stream and the North Brazil Current, consistent with the expected response from thermal wind balance (Supplementary Fig. 4; Methods). Noting that in addition to being affected by Kelvin waves25 under an AMOC weakening scenario, the intensity of the boundary currents can also be affected by freshwater advection through interior pathways41.In the equatorial Atlantic, Kelvin waves also contribute to the initial deepening of the mean equatorial thermocline. The suppressed eastern upwelling leads to intense rates of warming in the eastern equatorial Atlantic. This reinforces the reduced surface east-west SST gradient and, consequently, weakening of the trade winds, thus triggering the reversal of the thermocline slope. The deepening of the eastern equatorial thermocline suppresses the upwelling feedback (BF3) under AMOC weakening. It is important to note that while Kelvin waves play a significant role in reducing the zonal SST gradient along the equator, it is the interaction with atmospheric processes that ultimately shapes the final thermocline structure.As a result of these teleconnections mechanisms, when the AMOC collapses, there is a reversal in the direction of the trade winds (Fig. 2h), in the thermocline slope (Fig. 2e), and in the zonal SST gradient (Supplementary Fig. 1a). These changes result in increased heat content in the eastern Atlantic mixed-layer (Fig. 2d). Under this new configuration of the equatorial Atlantic, Atlantic Niños are likely triggered from the east (Fig. 1f), where heat anomalies propagate from east-to-west. In this scenario, easterly wind anomalies in the eastern Atlantic reactivate the upwelling on the African coast, displacing the eastern warm waters toward the central Atlantic, as indicated by a reversed relationship between eastern upwelling and ATL3 SSTs (BF3 red line in Fig. 2c). This mechanism is also consistent with the reversal of BF1 (red line in Fig. 2a), where positive SST anomalies in ATL3 are now related to easterly wind anomalies, further contributing to the advection of positive SST anomalies from east to west. These results indicate that the more centred equatorial Atlantic mode driven by an AMOC shutdown operates through substantially different ocean-atmosphere feedbacks. The absence of a positive upwelling feedback when the AMOC collapses suggests that the more centred pattern could be associated with reduced amplitude.Changes in atmospheric meridional heat transport also affect the mean state and variability of the tropical Pacific and Indian oceans that can in turn affect the Atlantic Ocean16. To investigate the possible role of the Pacific ocean in the Atlantic Niño weakening, we evaluate changes in the intensity of the equatorial trade winds and ENSO amplitude, as persistent increased ENSO activity can lead to weaker Atlantic trades, thus reducing Atlantic Niño activity15. These uncertainties stem from various factors, including different global warming scenarios55, systematic model biases, ice sheet melt25 and internal climate dynamics57,58. As such, the projected Atlantic Niño decline will likely be tied to the rate of the AMOC slow-down. The atmospheric component is the UK Met Office Unified Model (UM) version 7.359 configured at 1.875∘ longitude by 1.25∘ latitude with 38 vertical levels, extending from the surface to 40 km. The land component, which includes biogeochemistry, is the CABLE model60 and is directly coupled to the atmospheric model. The oceanic component is the Modular Ocean Model version 5 (MOM5)61 from the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory of the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA-GFDL). The horizontal ocean grid has a nominal resolution of 1∘. The latitudinal resolution is higher at the equator (0.33∘) and in the Southern Ocean (0.4∘ at 70∘S). This component has 50 vertical levels, with 20 evenly spaced levels (10 metres in the first 200 metres of the water column). The sea ice component is the Los Alamos National Laboratory CICE model version 4.162, which runs on the same grid as the ocean model.Idealised meltwater experimentsACCESS-ESM1.5 is spun up under CMIP6 pre-industrial setup for 1,000 years31. From this state, a meltwater experiment is conducted by adding 0.4 Sv (1 Sv = 106 m3. s−1) of freshwater uniformly in the subpolar North Atlantic (50∘N to 70∘N) for 500 years. Although this forcing lacks realism, it’s valuable for studying climate impacts resulting from an AMOC collapse. Throughout the simulation, atmospheric CO2 concentration remains constant at the pre-industrial level (i.e., 284ppm), ensuring that any observed variations are solely due to the climatic effects of freshwater input. In this study, the control run under pre-industrial conditions is named AMOC-on, while the period at which AMOC stabilizes at around 3 Sv is referred to as AMOC-off.Historical and future projection experimentsWe use a 10-member ensemble of CMIP6 historical simulations from the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model63. These simulations incorporate observed climate forcings such as greenhouse gases, aerosols, and changes in land use. Additionally, we perform an extra 8-member ensemble of historical simulations with freshwater input in the subpolar North Atlantic (59∘N-72∘N and 65∘W-22∘W). This region is smaller than the one used in ‘idealized’ experiments and focuses on meltwater and solid ice runoff from Greenland and Arctic glaciers. The freshwater input experimental design is based on the evolution of observation-based SST and salinity AMOC indices25,45,64, Greenland warming, sea-ice retreat and changes in Greenland surface mass balance (Supplementary Fig. 5). Meltwater forcing in these historical simulations begins in 1960 with a constant input of 0.05 Sv until 1989, corresponding to a rapid sea-ice retreat and Greenland warming trend65. From 1990 to 1999, observational data suggest a nearly constant sea-ice extent and no significant changes in Greenland surface mass balance. As such, no freshwater forcing is applied during this period. From 2000, observations indicate substantial Greenland warming and ice loss and a nearly 30% sea-ice retreat. 0.05 Sv freshwater input is thus applied between 2000 and 2004, increasing to 0.075 Sv from 2005 to 2014, which marks the end of the CMIP6 historical protocol. This scenario simulates a continuous Greenland warming throughout the 21st century, but no meltwater flux or ice discharge due to the melting of the Greenland ice-sheet or Arctic glaciers is included. To evaluate a more realistic scenario, we consider a ssp585 experiment with a linear increase in freshwater input in the subpolar Atlantic. This is implemented through decadal increments of 0.025 Sv starting from 0.1 Sv in 2020. From 2014 to 2019, a freshwater input of 0.075 Sv is kept, corresponding to the forcing at the end of the historical simulations. The combined historical and ssp585 experiments with freshwater input are referred in the main text as access-fw, while standard CMIP6 ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulations of the same scenarios are referred as access-cmip. These equations can be derived from the horizontal geostrophic components.                     (2)
                Where p(x, y, z) is the pressure, u(x, y, z) and v(x, y, z) are the zonal and meridional velocities respectively, ρ(x, y, z) is the seawater density and f in the Coriolis parameter on the f-plane. Climate change impacts on ocean light in Arctic ecosystems
                    Trond Kristiansen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-6121-297X1,2, Øystein Varpe 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5895-69833,4, Elizabeth R. Selig

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsEnvironmental healthPhenologyPhysical oceanography

AbstractClimate change is causing major sea ice losses, leading to increased light availability across polar marine ecosystems, however the consequences are largely unknown. We quantify how future conditions for sea ice and snow, storm-driven waves, clouds, ozone, air and ocean temperature, and chlorophyll-a will affect seasonal absorption and reflection of light in Arctic seas, alongside growth and survival of fish. Using four CMIP6 model inputs and a spectral radiative transfer model, we predict a 75–160% increase in visible light by 2100 in the Northern Bering, Chukchi, and Barents Seas. We predict increased sunlight and warmer summer waters, with reduced phytoplankton levels, will negatively impact cold-water fish species growth and survival during summer, demonstrated here for polar cod. Asynchrony in prey and light availability, with prolonged periods of warmer waters, will reduce polar cod survival in the fall and restrict habitats in these regions after 2060. Warmer-water species like walleye pollock and Atlantic cod will be less impacted but may struggle at high latitudes during the polar night. Ocean warming coupled with increased light availability will accelerate changes in Arctic ecosystems, compromising the growth and survival of Arctic species in transitional zones and facilitating the northward expansion of boreal species.

IntroductionLight is the primary driver for life in the world’s oceans but has been under-appreciated in assessments of climate change impacts on marine ecosystem1,2,3,4,5,6. Changes in the optical properties of the ocean’s skin regulate light penetration into the water column and influence a range of ecological processes such as the seasonal timing and amount of biological production7, species distribution8, and light-driven behavior and feeding9. Climate change-driven changes in the distribution, concentration, and thickness of sea ice, including the possibility of ice-free summers in the Arctic by 205010, portend a dramatic shift in seasonal light availability in polar ecosystems11. Given these predicted changes and the structuring role of light on Arctic species, a better understanding of changes in the quantity of seasonal light and subsequent impacts on ecological interactions is required to predict how future polar ecosystems may function.We quantify how climate change will affect light regimes in the Arctic using a new approach that allows for the detailed analysis of the large-scale spectral changes in shortwave radiation under climate change. To this end we combine individually published radiative transfer model (RTM) algorithms that are forced by CMIP6 climate model outputs and used to quantify the spectral albedo from waves and chlorophyll12,13, albedo from snow and ice12, and the spectral attenuation of light moving through clouds14, ozone15, ice16,17, snow18, and chlorophyll-a19 (Fig. 1). We selected two climate futures for the forcing data, the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSP) SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.520. Together, they represent the intermediate and extreme ranges of climate futures (figures show generally the SSP2-4.5 results, while SSP5-8.5 results, unless otherwise indicated, can be found in the supplementary). This study used outputs from four independent CMIP6 models across a range of model realizations, a total of 16 combinations (Supplementary Table 2), to quantify light. We combine RTM outputs using forcing from models with varying strengths21,22 to create an ensemble that is representative for model variability: the MPI-ESM1-2-LR model captures the trends in Arctic sea ice extent and thickness22, MPI-ESM1-2-HR has demonstrated strong ability to simulate Arctic conditions sea ice conditions21,23,24, UKESM1-0-LL has shown strong skills in projecting sea ice dynamics23,25, and CanESM5 has notable skill in decadal climate predictions26 and good ability to simulate Arctic Sea ice variability23,25. The RTM calculates direct normal irradiance (DNI) and diffuse horizontal irradiance (DHI) and we estimate the spectral albedo i) over the open ocean as a function of ocean waves and chlorophyll-a concentration, latitude, time of day and year, and ii) over sea ice and snow-covered seas. After accounting for reflection, the model attenuates the remaining light spectrally as it moves through the snow layer, sea ice, and chlorophyll-a. A sensitivity test of the RTM provided insights into how the individual components and parameterizations of the model impacted the outputs, and we have confidence in the model’s results based on these findings. The RTM results allow us to estimate the spectrally integrated light that reaches the upper part of the water column within the Arctic Ocean.Fig. 1: Climate change impacts on the ocean light.Future light regimes were modelled based on physical changes in ozone, clouds, waves, ice, snow and melt ponds as well as biological changes in chlorophyll, which all will impact reflection and absorption. We account for both direct and diffuse light from incoming shortwave radiation, albedo/reflection, and absorption. Ecosystem consequences of changing light are driven by a range of underlying mechanisms (circles). Most fish are visual feeders and require light to find their prey, while the development of fish eggs is temperature dependent. Phytoplankton particles can attenuate light, reducing visibility at depth (See Methods for details on the radiative transfer model).Full size imageHere, we focus on how light availability is expected to change within the Northern Bering and Chukchi and the Barents Seas27, which represent two highly biologically productive, but rapidly changing, seasonally sea ice covered ecosystems. With these results, we analyze changes in “visible light” or photosynthetic active radiation (PAR; 400–700 nm), which is an essential component of photosynthesis28. The amount of light reaching the water column also elevates ocean temperatures. We then analyze the spatially integrated temporal variability of light and temperature across geographic domains. We also examine UV-B light (280–315 nm), which can be a significant stressor for phytoplankton29, zooplankton30, and fish embryos31, and affects the development and growth of larval fish32. By comparing how these variables will change across the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and the Barents Sea large marine ecosystems (LMEs), we can estimate the consequences of shifting light and temperature regimes on the egg and juvenile stages of three abundant pelagic fish species in Arctic and sub-Arctic seas: polar cod (Boreogadus saida), walleye pollock (Gadus chalcogrammus), and Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua).Polar cod (or Arctic cod in the U.S.) is a bellwether species for assessing the impacts of changing light regimes on Arctic ecosystems because of their roles in trophic transfer, circumpolar distribution, and life history traits that are adapted to polar conditions33,34. Polar cod also spawn their eggs under or near sea ice, where they are protected from breaking waves and UV-B radiation in the surface layer32. Walleye pollock and Atlantic cod have adjacent or overlapping populations and are also abundant and commercially important34,35, but are more adapted to temperate conditions and therefore may be affected differently by changing light conditions. For all three of these fish species, the degree to which the timing of egg hatching coincides with phytoplankton and zooplankton blooms affects their immediate survival36, population dynamics37,38,39, and the potential energy transfer from zooplankton to higher trophic levels, such as seabirds and mammals33. For this study, we use climate model projections of chlorophyll-a as a proxy for food of planktivorous fish such as Polar cod and the larvae and juvenile stages of walleye pollock and Atlantic cod. Light calculations using the RTM provided us with ensemble estimates of seasonal variability of the euphotic conditions in the marine environment for two climate scenarios across 16 individual CMIP6 models and realizations. Our analyses highlight how warming and changing light availability impact the feeding, growth, and survival potential of these species, and with this information we illustrate potential consequences across Arctic food webs.ResultsChanges in photosynthetic active radiation (PAR) and its driversOverall, the projected decreases in sea ice and snow extent and thickness (Fig. 2, Supplementary Figs.1–3) will lead to elevated light conditions (Fig. 3, Supplementary Fig. 4). Enhanced light availability in the water column will then lead to increased ocean water temperatures (Fig. 2) and an extended open water season. The annual average area with open water within the Northern Bering and Chukchi and Barents Seas will increase from 50–55% in 1980 to 70–95% by 2100, depending on the climate scenario. We also estimate that the total area where light levels will exceed the minimum threshold40 for fish feeding of 0.1 W/m2 (Laurel pers. comm.) will increase by 25–30% and 14–16% in the Northern Bering and Chukchi and Barents Seas, respectively. Our choice of light threshold is based on one study and we realize that more research is needed to fully understand the effect of light levels on feeding. Based on climate scenarios SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 (Fig. 3, Supplementary Fig. 3), visible light (PAR) reaching the surface water column will increase by 55–160% annually by the year 2100 in response to the increased fraction of open water, mainly driven by reduced sea ice concentration (Fig. 2, Supplementary Figs. 1–3), as well as other changes in physical factors simulated in the CMIP6 future model runs (e.g., changes in cloud cover, increased air temperatures, reduced sea ice thickness). Reductions in snow and sea ice thickness and increased melt pond area due to warmer air temperatures will also contribute to more light entering the water column (Supplementary Figs. 1, 5).Fig. 2: Projected changes in ocean surface temperature and sea ice concentration.Expected changes in ocean surface temperature (°C) and sea ice concentration (%) for (a, c) the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and (b, d) the Barents Sea large marine ecosystems for climate change scenario SSP2-4.5. Projections are shown for each of the individual CMIP6 model and realization combinations used as forcing for the RTM. Thick blue and orange lines show the ensemble average without and with weighting based on skill and independence. Red dashed line (a, b) shows observed sea surface temperature from NOAA ERSSTv5 dataset67. Projected changes under SSP5-8.5 are shown in Supplementary Fig. 3.Full size imageFig. 3: Expected temporal changes in Photosynthetically Active Radiation (PAR).Changes in visible (PAR, Wm−2) annual average light in the ocean for (a) the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and (b) the Barents Sea large marine ecosystems for two scenarios of climate change, SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5. Average values are shown as solid lines with 95% confidence intervals in shading. Values are averaged across the LMEs with a 5-year rolling mean. The dashed lines show the relative change in % of PAR under SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 relative to the 1980–2000 average, with the scale on the right. Heatmaps showing the historical (1980–2000) monthly mean (leftmost column of each heatmap) and future decadal average changes in PAR (Wm−2) for (c) Northern Bering and Chukchi and (d) Barents Seas. Changes relative to historical values (1980–2000) are shown for each decade between 2000 and 2090 at 10-year intervals. Months with no change relative to historical values have no annotated values. Heatmaps depict results for SSP2-4.5, while Supplementary Fig. 4 shows SSP5-8.5.Full size imageTogether these physical conditions will further increase the heat content of surface waters through the ice-ocean albedo feedback loop41, leading to greater ice–melting, a physical dynamic unrelated to cloud cover. For both the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and Barents Sea, the average cloud cover remains nearly constant over the time period 1979–2100, at around 82% and 87%, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 2). An increase of 2% is found for the SSP5-8.5 scenario in the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea. These results suggest that changes in cloud cover are not a main driver of changes in PAR in the ocean, compared to the reduced extent and thickness of snow and sea ice. By 2050, annual average PAR is estimated to increase by 50–77% within each region compared to 1980–2000, with continued increases of 0.009–0.016 W m−2 y−1 (Fig. 3) until 2100. Seasonal strong increases in PAR, particularly between April and September, are expected under both SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5 (Fig. 3), while the winter months will continue to be relatively dark with only minor changes (Fig. 3). We also observe a sudden significant increase in PAR after 2050 for the SSP5-8.5 scenario in the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea. This could indicate that the system will then reach a tipping point potentially caused by the collapse of sea ice concentration and a strong increase in air and ocean temperatures.UV-B under climate changeOverall, we find only small changes in the average UV-B irradiance reaching the atmosphere-ice/ocean interface relative to 1980–2000 for both ecosystems (Fig. 4, top panels), although with pronounced decadal variability. UV-B levels from 1980 to 2100 are generally decreasing, with a range of 0 to −10% for SSP5-8.5 and −2% to +8% for SSP2-4.5. The UV-B decline also has a strong seasonal component (not shown), with the largest and most distinct changes in total column ozone (TCO) during late winter/spring and the smallest changes during summer, while autumn has large variability. The decrease in annually averaged UV-B irradiance is driven by increased TCO, consistent with the future recovery of the stratospheric ozone layer following the Montreal Protocol regulations15. The stronger increase is found under the SSP5-8.5 scenario (Fig. 4, bottom panels),with TCO expected to reach levels equal to around 50 DU (or 10–15%) higher than 1960 values by 2100 (Fig. 4e). Increases under SSP2-4.5 reach values of 20 DU (5–8%). These results are generally consistent with previous estimates of 10–18% decreases in UV radiation under the RCP4.5 and 8.5 scenarios over the 21st century, as derived from simulations from the IGAC/SPARC Chemistry-Climate Model Initiative. Overall, the projected changes in stratospheric ozone will decrease UV-B irradiance for both the Northern Bering and Chukchi and Barents Seas. Still, the amount of UV-B irradiance projected to reach the top of the water column is increasing substantially (Fig. 4, middle panels) by up to 70% by 2100. This is a consequence of the increased fraction of open water of each LME.Fig. 4: Expected temporal changes in UV-B and TCO.Projected changes in incoming UV-B (Wm−2) radiation at the atmosphere-ice/ocean interface are shown in top panel, while irradiance reaching the surface layer of the water column is shown in the middle panels for the (a) Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and (b) the Barents Sea LMEs for two scenarios SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5. Solid lines show average values with standard deviation in shading. Values are averaged across each LME with a 5-year rolling mean. The dashed lines indicate the relative changes in %-value from the 1980–2000 average (with the scale on the right). The bottom panel shows timeseries of total column ozone (TCO) for SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5.Full size imageChanges in chlorophyll-aProjected chlorophyll-a from CMIP6 models suggests a general increase in biological productivity at high latitudes, but variability across models is high (Supplementary Fig. 1). This variability could be related to differences in model representations of nutrient advection, mixing, and grazing from zooplankton42. Our results reflect this variability. Under climate scenario SSP2-4.5, projected CMIP6 chlorophyll-a values suggest increases in annual average chlorophyll-a content of 2.5 ± 14.5% in the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and 11.7 ± 16.7% in the Barents Sea. We estimated these values as the annual averages from the period 2080–2100 relative to 1980–2000. Conversely, there is a decrease of 3.7 ± 1.9% in chlorophyll-a content for the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and an increase of 7.7 ± 13.7% in the Barents Sea for the same periods under SSP5-8.5. Overall, we find there is high uncertainty in estimates of future chlorophyll-a concentrations. In contrast, we predict a clear change in the seasonality of chlorophyll-a under both SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5, with the spring bloom estimated to occur earlier for each future decade (Fig. 5, Supplementary Fig. 6). However, the magnitude of change seen in SSP5-8.5 is delayed or lagged by a decade compared to SSP2-4.5. Due to this temporal shift, the Barents Sea chlorophyll-a abundance during May is estimated to increase by 30–50% between 2000 and 2080, while the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea may experience an increase of 20% by 2080. The Northern Bering and Chukchi and Barents Seas are projected to experience 10–50% reductions in chlorophyll abundance in summer (July–September). The same trends and changes are found under SSP5-8.5, with only small differences (Supplementary Fig. 6).Fig. 5: Future decadal changes in temperature and chlorophyll-a abundance.Heatmaps show the historical (1980–2000) monthly mean (leftmost column of each heatmap) and future decadal average changes in ocean surface temperature (tos) (°C, left) in (a) the Barents Sea and (b) Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea and chlorophyll-a (mg/m3, right) for (c) Barents and (d) Northern Bering and Chukchi Seas under SSP2-4.5. Changes relative to historical values (1980–2000) are shown for each decade between 2000 and 2090 at 10-year intervals. Months with no change relative to historical values have no annotated value.Full size imageChanges in seasonal environmental variability and impacts on pelagic fishBy using laboratory-derived34 functions for temperature-driven polar cod egg survival (Table 1, Supplementary Fig. 7) and assumptions of i) no acclimation or adaptation and ii) eggs are also in areas without sea ice, we estimate that the projected 1.2–2 °C increase during winter (January–March) in the Barents Sea open surface water temperature may decrease egg hatching success from 85% to 73% by 2100 under SSP2-4.5, or to 63% under SSP5-8.5. Expected temperature changes during winter in the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea are negligible, and therefore, survival during the egg stage remains unchanged for polar cod as well as for warmer-water walleye pollock (Supplementary Fig. 8). Egg survival within the Barents Sea could increase from 67% to 75% for Atlantic cod (Supplementary Fig. 9) as the duration of the egg stage for that species is shortened.Table 1 Theoretical optimal temperature for maximum egg survival and juvenile growth rates for Atlantic cod, polar cod, and walleye pollockFull size tableIn contrast to the egg stage, juvenile stages of polar cod grow successfully and survive over a much wider thermal window (−1 to 12 °C) in laboratory studies43 (Supplementary Fig. 7). However, mortality typically increases with warming waters as aerobic scope, or the ability to perform aerobic activities, declines. The expected increases in temperature during spring (April–June) within the Northern Bering and Chukchi and Barents Seas are within the tolerance limits for juvenile polar cod, suggesting they may experience elevated growth rates given sufficient food (Fig. 5). Juvenile growth rates for walleye pollock in the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea show that they could also benefit from expected warming, reaching their preferred temperature range by 2050–2060 (Supplementary Fig. 8). In the Barents Sea, warmer conditions will also favor the growth of juvenile Atlantic cod (Supplementary Fig. 9). Hence, all three species may, at least for some period into the future, potentially benefit from warming during the more thermally-flexible juvenile stage.However, as for all ectotherms, these fish species will increase their metabolic demands with warming and thereby their vulnerability to prey mismatch39. Our calculations suggest that prey abundance will peak earlier (May and April) and have lower levels later in the season (July–September) (Fig. 5) under SSP2-4.5, with even lower levels under SSP5-8.5 (Supplementary Fig. 6). At the same time, expected changes in decadal average ocean temperatures relative to the historical period 1980–2000 suggest that monthly average temperatures will increase by 2.8 °C (0.5 °C) in winter (January) and by 5.1 °C (4.0 °C) during summer (July) by 2100 in the Barents Sea (Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea) under SSP2-4.5 (Fig. 5). These changes are even stronger under SSP5-8.5, with monthly average temperatures increasing by 3.7 °C (1.7 °C) in winter and 6.8 °C (6.9 °C) during summer by 2100 in the Barents Sea (Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea) (Supplementary Fig. S6). The thermal threshold of 4.5 °C for polar cod eggs suggests that expected temperatures will be lethal under SSP5-8.5 by the end of the century (Supplementary Fig. S6).Further complicating survival are seasonal light changes. Polar cod can visually detect prey when light levels exceed a minimum threshold of 0.1 Wm−2 (0.457 μmol photons m−2 s−1) (Laurel pers. comm.), where diminished foraging success appears to occur. This threshold was used as it is in the same range as other cold-water gadid larvae (e.g., Northern Atlantic cod40). In the spring, more light due to increased ice-free habitats and subsequently warmer temperatures create conditions favorable for increased larvae and juvenile polar cod growth in both regions. Under SSP2-4.5, the period during winter and spring when PAR exceeds the minimum threshold in the water column will gradually increase from 2.5 to 5 months by 2100 in the Northern Bering and Chukchi Sea, while in the Barents Sea it will increase from 3 to 4.5 months (Fig. 6). However, we find that future increased solar radiation reaching a larger ice-free surface area will raise ocean temperatures and create positive feedback loops that accelerate ice melt, further warming the water column in a process known as Arctic amplification44. Predicted rates of warming may outpace the adaptive capacity of many Arctic fish species45, particularly those species near the southern limits of their range (e.g., polar cod in the Bering and Barents seas) that are already at the edge of their thermal tolerance limits46. Furthermore, elevated light levels will result in a gradual accumulation of heat during the summer months. As summer concludes and light intensity diminishes, the ocean’s heat content may persist at elevated levels for an extended duration. Our results suggest that the combined impacts of reduced snow, thinning sea ice, increased fraction of open water surface area (50–55%, Supplementary Fig. 3), increased light (75–160%, Fig. 3), increased ocean temperatures ( <6.8 °C, Fig. 7), and seasonal shifts in phytoplankton (Fig. 5) in the current light- and nutrient-limited focal ecosystems will cause large changes in the abundance, growth, and survival of key species from phytoplankton to fish.
